study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence for the benefits of whey and other dietary protein supplementation in the elderly, focusing on lean body mass and health parameters, and to define optimal protein intake strategies.
results_summary: The study suggests that an intake of approximately 0.4 g protein/kg BW per meal (1.2-1.6 g protein/kg BW/day) may be beneficial for the elderly to maintain lean body mass and improve health, though potential anabolic resistance and risks of excessive protein intake were noted.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals
effective_dosage: 0.4 g protein/kg BW per meal (1.2-1.6 g protein/kg BW/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of choline supplementation on plasma amino acid status in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) and pancreatic insufficiency (PI).
results_summary: Choline supplementation did not affect methionine-homocysteine metabolism but altered glycine, threonine, histidine, valine, and branched-chain amino acid levels. Baseline dietary protein intake was high, and amino acid profiles were mostly within reference ranges, with some elevated alanine and cysteine levels.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-18 years with CF and PI.
effective_dosage: Choline-enriched structured lipid (LYM-X-SORB) or placebo with similar energy and fat content (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of a ketoanalogue-supplemented vegetarian very low-protein diet (KD) versus a conventional low-protein diet (LPD) in delaying CKD progression and dialysis initiation.
results_summary: The KD showed significant efficacy in delaying dialysis initiation, particularly in patients with eGFR<20 ml/min per 1.73 m², with an adjusted NNT of 2.7. The diet was nutritionally safe, with no adverse reactions or changes in nutritional parameters.
population_specificity: Nondiabetic adults with stable eGFR<30 ml/min per 1.73 m², proteinuria <1 g/g urinary creatinine, good nutritional status, and good diet compliance.
effective_dosage: KD: 0.3 g/kg vegetable proteins and 1 cps/5 kg ketoanalogues per day; LPD: 0.6 g/kg per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased dietary protein intake, specifically 30 g/d of whey protein, could improve muscle mass and physical function in older women.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of whey protein supplementation on muscle mass or physical function over 2 years, despite a confirmed increase in protein intake. Both groups showed declines in upper arm and calf muscle area and hand grip strength.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older Australian women aged 70-80 years (mean 74.3 ± 2.7 y), with a baseline protein intake of 76 ± 17 g/d.
effective_dosage: 30 g of whey protein daily (high protein group) vs. 2.1 g protein daily (placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary protein supplementation before sleep enhances muscle mass and strength gains during resistance exercise training in young men.
results_summary: Protein supplementation before sleep significantly increased muscle strength and hypertrophy compared to placebo, with greater improvements in quadriceps cross-sectional area and type II muscle fiber size. The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Young men (22 ± 1 years)
effective_dosage: 27.5 g protein, 15 g carbohydrate, and 0.1 g fat nightly before sleep

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of varying doses of liquid whey protein on subjective appetite sensations and food intake in athletes.
results_summary: All protein doses (20-80 g) significantly reduced hunger ratings by 50-65%, but higher doses did not further increase satiety or reduce food intake. The study concluded that additional whey protein supplementation beyond 20 g did not measurably affect satiety or energy intake.
population_specificity: Ten male athletes (21.2 ± 2.3 years) who performed both resistance and aerobic training.
effective_dosage: 20, 40, 60, or 80 g of whey protein consumed once per testing session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how resistance exercise and nutrition, particularly dietary protein sources and non-protein nutrients like omega-3 fatty acids, regulate muscle protein synthesis and breakdown to counteract muscle loss.
results_summary: The study reviewed classical and contemporary work, highlighting the role of dietary protein and exercise in regulating muscle protein turnover, with special attention to different protein sources and novel 'omic' technologies. It suggests potential benefits of dietary protein and omega-3 fatty acids in maintaining muscle mass but calls for further research.
population_specificity: General focus on ageing populations at risk of sarcopenia, but not limited to a specific demographic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of total protein intake (TPro) and changes in TPro (CTPro) on body composition and metabolic syndrome indexes in overweight and obese middle-aged adults participating in an exercise program.
results_summary: Higher TPro was inversely associated with reductions in body mass, fat mass, and BMI, with the most favorable changes observed in the group consuming 1.0 to <1.2 g/kg/d. However, metabolic syndrome indexes were unaffected by TPro or CTPro.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese middle-aged adults (n = 117; age 50 ± 0.7 years, BMI 30.1 ± 0.3).
effective_dosage: 0, 10, 20, or 30 g whey protein twice daily (as part of 200-kcal supplements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of dietary protein in mitigating age-related muscle loss (sarcopenia) and the phenomenon of anabolic resistance in the elderly.
results_summary: The study found that low dietary protein intake exacerbates muscle loss in the elderly and that anabolic resistance may impair muscle protein synthesis. However, protein supplementation, especially when combined with resistance exercise, could help counteract these effects and delay muscle mass decline.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals experiencing or at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the associations between protein-energy wasting (PEW), muscle wasting, cachexia, and mortality in chronic kidney disease (CKD) and evaluate dietary protein management strategies.
results_summary: The study found that adequate energy supplementation combined with a low-protein diet may prevent PEW in CKD patients, though protein requirements may increase with aging and dialysis. Muscle loss was more strongly associated with poor outcomes than fat loss, and phosphorus burden could lead to adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), including those on dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the satiating power of an omelette and cottage cheese, both containing similar macronutrient compositions, to determine if protein kinetics influence satiety.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in satiety, time until next meal, or energy intake between the omelette and cottage cheese, despite differences in protein kinetics and hormone secretion. Plasma amino acid and urea concentrations showed delayed kinetics with eggs, but glucose, triglycerides, and cholesterol profiles were similar.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy volunteers (with a subgroup of 10 for blood sampling).
effective_dosage: 26 g protein per snack (1346 kJ, 21 g lipids, 8 g lactose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of dietary protein in supporting muscle mass maintenance or gain in active older adults and its impact on healthier aging.
results_summary: The study found that dietary protein, when consumed close to physical activity, can overcome the blunted muscle protein synthetic response in older adults, leading to muscle maintenance or hypertrophy. Optimal type and amount of protein further enhance these effects.
population_specificity: Active older adults (aging population at risk of sarcopenia)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary protein supplementation (∼20 g twice daily) could preserve muscle mass during short-term limb immobilization in healthy older men.
results_summary: Protein supplementation did not attenuate muscle loss or strength decline during 5 days of immobilization. Both groups showed similar reductions in muscle cross-sectional area and strength, with no significant differences between them.
population_specificity: Healthy older men (average age 69 ± 1 years)
effective_dosage: 20.7 g of protein, 9.3 g of carbohydrate, and 3.0 g of fat, administered twice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and nutritional outcomes, including dietary protein effects, in morbidly obese patients undergoing biliopancreatic diversion with different channel lengths.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight loss between groups but noted higher morbidity (e.g., protein malnutrition, anemia) in patients with shorter common channels, linked to poor dietary protein intake compliance.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients who underwent biliopancreatic diversion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey-protein supplementation combined with vitamin D could enhance the effects of progressive resistance training on glycaemic control, muscle mass, and cardiometabolic health in older adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study evaluated the combined effects of whey-protein and vitamin D with resistance training but did not report specific results in the abstract; the findings were intended to provide new evidence on glycaemic control, muscle mass, and cardiometabolic risk factors.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 50-75 years with type 2 diabetes, treated with diet alone or oral hypoglycaemic agents (not insulin).
effective_dosage: 20 g daily of whey-protein plus 20 g after each resistance training session, and 2000 IU/day of vitamin D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary protein and amino acid supplementation in improving muscle protein balance and skeletal muscle maintenance, particularly in hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The study found that dietary protein and amino acid supplementation (∼30 g protein and ∼3 g leucine) stimulates skeletal muscle protein anabolism in older adults, potentially counteracting muscle atrophy and functional decline during inactivity. It suggests these interventions may support muscle maintenance in hospitalized older adults.
population_specificity: Healthy, community-dwelling older adults and hospitalized older adults.
effective_dosage: ∼30 g protein and ∼3 g leucine (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a protein-supplemented food service concept could increase protein and energy intake in hospitalized patients at nutritional risk.
results_summary: The intervention group had significantly higher protein intake (66% vs. 30% meeting requirements) and weight-adjusted energy intake compared to the control group, though body weight, handgrip strength, and hospital stay duration did not differ.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients at nutritional risk from Oncology, Orthopaedics, and Urology departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher protein intake (≥ 3.0 g/kg/d) versus lower protein intake (< 3.0 g/kg/d) in formula-fed preterm or low birth weight infants improves growth and neurodevelopmental outcomes without short- or long-term morbidity.
results_summary: Higher protein intake (≥ 3.0 g/kg/d but < 4.0 g/kg/d) improved weight gain and nitrogen accretion, but very high protein intake (≥ 4.0 g/kg/d) was associated with uremia in some infants and a higher incidence of low IQ scores in very low birth weight infants. No significant differences were found in necrotizing enterocolitis, sepsis, or diarrhea rates.
population_specificity: Formula-fed preterm or low birth weight infants (< 2.5 kg).
effective_dosage: Low (< 3.0 g/kg/d), high (≥ 3.0 g/kg/d but < 4.0 g/kg/d), very high (≥ 4.0 g/kg/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms behind high-protein diets' ability to prevent diet-induced obesity and improve metabolic disorders, focusing on leucine supplementation and its effects.
results_summary: High-protein diets prevented diet-induced obesity and improved metabolic disorders in mice, with leucine supplementation partially mimicking these effects. The study suggests a link between high amino nitrogen intake, obligatory water consumption, and potential reductions in lipid storage and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary protein supplementation affects mitochondrial adaptations and skeletal muscle intracellular signaling following aerobic exercise.
results_summary: High-quality protein supplementation enhances anabolic skeletal muscle intracellular signaling and mitochondrial protein synthesis after aerobic exercise, potentially improving mitochondrial biogenesis and exercise performance. The mechanisms of how carbohydrate restriction and protein supplementation together affect these adaptations remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general aerobic exercise participants implied).
study_duration: Not specified (single bout of aerobic exercise mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 24-week dietary protein supplementation improves cognitive performance in pre-frail and frail elderly people.
results_summary: Protein supplementation improved reaction time more than placebo but had no significant effect on other cognitive domain scores (episodic memory, attention, working memory, information processing speed, or executive functioning).
population_specificity: Pre-frail and frail elderly subjects (average age 79 ± 8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of protein supplementation combined with home-based exercises on physical performance in home-dwelling older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study was still in progress at the time of publication.
population_specificity: Home-dwelling older adults (75+) in Porvoo, Finland, diagnosed with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence of protein supplement use among military personnel and assess potential benefits under metabolic stressors like inadequate dietary intake during strenuous operations.
results_summary: The study found that protein supplements may not be necessary for most military personnel with adequate protein and energy intake (~1.5 g/kg/day), but could help preserve fat-free mass in dismounted infantry facing prolonged physical activity and dietary deficits.
population_specificity: U.S. military personnel, particularly active-duty warfighters and dismounted infantry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nitrogen balance is optimal for protein synthesis and whether higher dietary protein intake could benefit warfighters under metabolic and mental stress.
results_summary: The study found that higher dietary protein intake (2-3 times the RDA) can mitigate reductions in lean mass and protein synthesis during negative energy balance, suggesting benefits for warfighters in high-stress conditions. However, long-term inadequate protein intake leads to reduced metabolic and physiological function.
population_specificity: Warfighters engaged in combat and high-stress field operations.
effective_dosage: 2-3 times the RDA (approximately 1.6-2.4 g protein · kg(-1) · d(-1)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dietary protein intake on muscle mass preservation in older adults, particularly addressing age-related sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that higher dietary protein intake may reduce the decline in lean/muscle mass in older adults, though chronic protein supplementation showed mixed results in preserving muscle mass. Acute protein ingestion appeared to overcome age-related blunting of protein synthesis.
population_specificity: Adults over the age of 60, particularly those at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low-protein diet, with or without keto acid supplementation, on nutritional status and proteinuria in patients with HBV and early-stage chronic glomerulonephritis.
results_summary: The study found that keto acid supplementation with a low-protein diet significantly reduced proteinuria and microalbuminuria compared to baseline and the low-protein-only group, while also improving nutritional parameters like serum albumin and prealbumin. No significant differences were observed in serum creatinine or glomerular filtration rate.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic glomerulonephritis and HBV infection (n=17).
effective_dosage: Low-protein diet (0.6-0.8 g/kg ideal body weight per day) with or without keto acid supplementation (0.1 g/kg ideal body weight per day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary protein and essential amino acid supplementation on muscle mass preservation during periods of disuse, particularly in older patients at risk of sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that maintaining protein intake during disuse attenuates muscle atrophy, and supplementation with dietary protein or essential amino acids can further aid in muscle mass preservation. Prolonged disuse reduces muscle protein synthesis, but early transient increases in protein breakdown may also contribute to atrophy.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy humans undergoing disuse (e.g., recovery from injury or illness), with particular relevance to older patients at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation enhances muscle mass and strength gains during prolonged resistance-type exercise training in younger and older populations.
results_summary: Protein supplementation significantly increased fat-free mass and leg press strength compared to placebo, with statistically significant results (P < 0.00001 for FFM, P < 0.005 for 1-RM). The effects were consistent across both younger and older subjects.
population_specificity: Younger and older subjects engaging in resistance-type exercise training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary protein in managing hepatic encephalopathy (HE) in patients with cirrhosis, focusing on nutritional strategies and safety considerations.
results_summary: The study found that dietary protein intake of 1.2-1.5g/kg daily is recommended for patients with cirrhosis and HE, with small meals and late-night snacks to minimize protein utilization. Diets rich in vegetables and dairy protein may be beneficial, though tolerance varies, and branched-chain amino acid supplements could help protein-intolerant patients.
population_specificity: Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of 24 weeks of dietary protein supplementation on muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in frail elderly people.
results_summary: Protein supplementation improved physical performance but did not increase skeletal muscle mass. Muscle strength increased in both groups, with a trend toward greater improvement in the protein group.
population_specificity: Frail elderly subjects (n=65)
effective_dosage: 15 g protein at breakfast and lunch daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary protein supplementation (15 g·d⁻¹) could enhance muscle mass, strength, and functional capacity gains from resistance training in healthy elderly men and women.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training significantly increased muscle mass, strength, and functional capacity in elderly participants, but additional protein supplementation did not further improve these outcomes compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly men (n = 31, 70 ± 1 yr) and women (n = 29, 70 ± 1 yr).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether whey protein as an immunonutrient could improve enteral nutrition tolerance, reduce inflammation, and enhance anti-inflammatory defenses in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that enteral nutrition enriched with whey protein may improve gut function, reduce inflammation, enhance muscle strength, and prevent complications like cardiovascular disease and osteoporosis in critically ill patients.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with impaired gastric motor function and feed intolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether protein supplementation enhances muscle mass, strength, and physical performance during resistance exercise training in frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: Protein supplementation increased lean body mass in frail elderly participants, while strength and physical performance improved in both protein and placebo groups without additional benefit from protein.
population_specificity: Frail elderly men and women (average age 78 ± 1 year)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding ricotta cheese (a protein-rich food) to the habitual diet of elderly sarcopenic individuals would increase total appendicular skeletal muscle mass and strength.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in total appendicular skeletal muscle mass between groups, but muscle strength improved in the intervention group (though only tending toward significance). Secondary analysis showed benefits in men, including increased muscle mass, improved insulin levels, and enhanced strength.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic elderly men and women over 60 years of age (n = 40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize plasma amino acid responses to 20 g of protein from different sources and assess the impact of exercise on these responses.
results_summary: The study found that liquid protein forms achieved peak amino acid concentrations faster than solid protein-rich foods, with skim milk showing the fastest peak leucine concentration. Exercise before protein intake did not significantly alter the pattern of amino acid delivery but increased the rate of elimination by 20-40%.
population_specificity: 15 untrained and overnight-fasted subjects (Study 1); 10 endurance-trained subjects (Study 2).
study_duration: Plasma AA concentrations were measured for 180 min after ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary protein restriction in managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) by reducing waste accumulation and improving metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that dietary protein restriction helps decrease nitrogen waste, hydrogen ions, and phosphates while maintaining nutritional status, potentially delaying renal replacement and improving CKD outcomes. A consensus supports dietary manipulation as a key approach in CKD management.
population_specificity: Predialysis, dialysis, and transplanted CKD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish protein supplementation, rather than just increasing protein intake, could improve glucose and lipid metabolism in overweight adults.
results_summary: Fish protein supplementation for 8 weeks reduced fasting glucose, postprandial glucose, glucose-AUC, and LDL-cholesterol while improving body composition (increased muscle %, reduced fat %). Insulin C-peptide levels also showed favorable changes.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (n=34)
effective_dosage: 3 g/d for the first 4 weeks, then 6 g/d for the last 4 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing dietary protein intake (∼25% of energy intake) compared to carbohydrate intake lowers office and daytime blood pressure in adults with elevated BP.
results_summary: Increased protein intake significantly reduced office systolic and diastolic blood pressure (4.9 mm Hg and 2.7 mm Hg, respectively) and daytime systolic blood pressure (4.6 mm Hg) compared to maltodextrin, with no difference in daytime diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (BMI 25-35) aged 20-70 with untreated elevated BP (130/85 to <160/100 mm Hg).
effective_dosage: 3 × 20 g protein per day (20% pea, 20% soy, 30% egg, 30% milk-protein isolate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soy protein, milk protein, and carbohydrate supplementation on blood pressure in adults with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension.
results_summary: Both soy and milk protein supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure compared to carbohydrate controls, with no significant difference between the two protein types. Diastolic blood pressure also decreased, though not statistically significantly.
population_specificity: Adults with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension in New Orleans, LA, and Jackson, MS.
study_duration: 8 weeks per intervention phase, with a 3-week washout between phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein (WP), soy protein (SP), and carbohydrate (CHO) supplementation on body weight and composition in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: WP supplementation resulted in lower body weight and fat mass compared to CHO, but no differences were observed between SP and WP or SP and CHO. Waist circumference was smaller in the WP group, and fasting ghrelin was lower in WP compared to SP or CHO.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese but otherwise healthy participants.
effective_dosage: ~56 g/d of protein (WP or SP) or an isoenergetic amount of CHO, consumed twice daily as a beverage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of maternal dietary protein supplementation to improve fetal growth and prevent intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), while also investigating adverse outcomes associated with high protein intake.
results_summary: The study found that high dietary protein supplementation in pregnant women led to adverse perinatal outcomes, though the mechanisms remain unclear. Animal and human data were reviewed to develop hypotheses for therapeutic interventions to safely address IUGR.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and animal models, focusing on those affected by or at risk of IUGR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with essential amino acids (EAAs) could reduce infection rates in elderly patients in a rehabilitative setting.
results_summary: The study found that EAA supplementation reduced infection rates from 82.5% in the placebo group to 52% in the EAA group (p<0.02). Higher serum albumin, hemoglobin, and dietary protein intake were associated with lower infection risk, while elevated CRP and low hemoglobin levels were linked to increased infection risk.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (average age ~80) admitted to a Geriatric Intensive Rehabilitation Center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between serum bicarbonate levels and long-term outcomes (kidney failure, mortality) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), as part of a broader study examining dietary protein restriction and blood pressure control.
results_summary: Lower serum bicarbonate levels were associated with higher risks of kidney failure, mortality, and composite outcomes, but these associations were not independent of baseline glomerular filtration rate (GFR). The study suggests bicarbonate supplementation might influence CKD progression, but further trials are needed.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic patients with stage 2-4 CKD (n=1,781, including screened non-randomized and randomized participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prolonged leucine supplementation could improve body composition, muscle mass, strength, glycemic control, and lipidemia in elderly type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found that 6 months of leucine supplementation (7.5 g/d) did not significantly alter lean tissue mass, body fat percentage, muscle strength, glycemic control, or plasma lipid concentrations compared to placebo. No differences were observed between the leucine and placebo groups in any measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly males with type 2 diabetes (age 71 ± 1 y; BMI 27.3 ± 0.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 2.5 g L-leucine with each main meal (total 7.5 g/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of vitamin C and zinc in children's growth and development, particularly their immune functions, and discuss their deficiency relevance in Asian and Latin American regions.
results_summary: The study found that deficiencies of vitamin C and zinc adversely affect children's physical and mental growth and impair immune defenses, with nutrition being the primary method for providing these nutrients, though supplementation can be supportive in developing regions.
population_specificity: Children in Asian and Latin American regions undergoing rapid nutritional transition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which Dihydroberberine (dhBBR) affects premature ovarian insufficiency (POI), particularly its role in regulating the Th17/Treg cell balance and the Rheb/mTOR pathway.
results_summary: dhBBR improved ovarian function in a dose-dependent manner, reduced ovarian cell apoptosis, increased cell proliferation, and shifted the Th17/Treg cell balance toward Treg cells. It targeted the Rheb/mTOR pathway to promote CD4+ cell differentiation into Treg cells, alleviating POI.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice used as POI models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetic pathways and metabolite profiles of dihydroberberine (DHB) and micellar berberine (LMB) formulations in vitro and in human participants.
results_summary: DHB treatment resulted in higher blood concentrations of berberine and most metabolites compared to LMB, but LMB showed a higher proportion of unmetabolized berberine. Distinct metabolic pathways were observed for different metabolites between the two formulations.
population_specificity: Nine healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective role and underlying mechanism of Dihydroberberine (DHBB) in a dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced colitis model.
results_summary: DHBB effectively alleviated colitis symptoms, improved gut barrier function, and reduced immune-inflammatory responses by blocking the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway, performing similarly to azathioprine and better than berberine.
population_specificity: Acute colitis model in mice induced by DSS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-inflammatory properties and mechanisms of Dihydroberberine (DHB) and Berberine (BBR) in murine models of inflammation.
results_summary: DHB effectively reduced inflammation in three murine models, decreasing inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α, NO, PGE2) and inhibiting NF-κB and MAPK pathways, though its effect was weaker than BBR.
population_specificity: Inflammatory murine models (mice).

study_goal: To investigate the effect and molecular mechanisms of different doses of 8-hydroxy dihydroberberine (Hdber) for treating hyperlipidemia in rats.
results_summary: Hdber improved blood lipid profiles, decreased PCSK-9 protein expression, and increased LDL-R protein expression in hyperlipidemic rats, showing comparable efficacy to berberine.
population_specificity: Rats with hyperlipidemia induced by a high-fat diet.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (intervention followed 4 weeks of high-fat diet induction)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics, metabolism, and safety of transdermal dihydroberberine (DHB) and berberine (BBR) formulations against oral BBR to improve bioavailability and reduce side effects.
results_summary: Transdermal DHB showed significantly higher bioavailability than oral BBR, with no adverse effects on liver or kidney biomarkers and no interference with simvastatin metabolism. Chronic administration maintained elevated BBR and metabolite levels without safety concerns.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats
interactions: None mentioned with simvastatin; no effect on CYP3A4 expression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the intestinal absorption of berberine (Ber) and 8-hydroxy dihydroberberine (Hdber) and their effects on sugar absorption to explain Hdber's low-dose, high-activity mechanism in treating hyperglycemia.
results_summary: Hdber showed significantly higher intestinal absorption (>70%) compared to Ber (<10%). Both compounds inhibited glucose and sucrose absorption, but Hdber exhibited stronger inhibitory effects (P<0.01).
population_specificity: Rat small intestine (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumour effects of dihydroberberine combined with sunitinib (DCS) on human non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: DCS showed synergistic effects on inhibiting NCI-H460 cell proliferation, colony formation, and tumour growth, down-regulated key signaling pathways (JNK, p38, NF-κB), and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine secretion. The combination enhanced sensitivity to sunitinib and altered cell cycle-related molecules.
population_specificity: Human non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines (A549, NCI-H460, NCI-H1299) and transplantable tumours.

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Dill or its effects.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide any results related to Dill.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age (15-49) with vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of AMPK activation by berberine (BBR) and determine if its derivative, dihydroberberine (dhBBR), improved in vivo efficacy for treating insulin resistance and adiposity in high-fat-fed rodents.
results_summary: The study found that dhBBR improved in vivo efficacy by counteracting adiposity, tissue triglyceride accumulation, and insulin resistance in high-fat-fed rodents, likely due to enhanced oral bioavailability compared to BBR.
population_specificity: High-fat-fed rodents (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of drug-induced liver injury (DILL) associated with liraglutide use in a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that liraglutide may cause rare but severe liver injury, as evidenced by elevated liver enzymes in a patient, which resolved after discontinuation of the drug. The abstract highlights the need for increased physician awareness of this potential side effect.
population_specificity: A 41-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus, fatty liver disease, and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Dill seeds in reducing pain and systemic symptoms associated with dysmenorrhea compared to other spices.
results_summary: Dill seeds were found to be effective in reducing pain in dysmenorrheic subjects, outperforming ginger and cumin. However, cumin showed significant reduction in systemic symptoms like cold sweats, backache, fatigue, and cramps.
population_specificity: Dysmenorrheic adolescent and adult females.
effective_dosage: 3gr/day for three days during each menstrual cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the influence of kaempferol (KMP), a phytochemical found in dill, on intracellular cascades regulating metabolism and signaling in breast, ovarian, and cervical cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that KMP, present in dill, exhibits anticancer effects by modulating cellular signal transduction pathways linked to apoptosis, inflammation, angiogenesis, and metastasis, without harming normal cells. It triggers cancer cell death through mechanisms like cell cycle arrest, caspase activation, and metabolic alteration.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (breast, ovarian, cervical) in vitro or in preclinical models (not explicitly specified for human trials).

study_goal: To develop and validate a simple qualitative procedure for detecting chloroquine in urine using the Dill-Glazko's test and confirmatory spectrophotometry.
results_summary: The confirmatory test showed better recovery and higher sensitivity (90%) compared to Baselt's method (83.3%), with a detection limit of 5mg/L. The combination of Dill-Glazko's test and confirmatory testing had a detection limit of 15mg/L and demonstrated suitability for clinical toxicology.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of consistent vitamin K intake in patients on warfarin, using the case of a patient who stopped consuming dill pickles as an example.
results_summary: The study found that abrupt cessation of dill pickle consumption (a source of vitamin K) in a patient on warfarin led to an elevated INR, indicating increased bleeding risk. It emphasizes the need for consistent vitamin K intake and awareness of vitamin K-rich foods, including pickles, in warfarin therapy.
population_specificity: A 36-year-old woman with lupus and antiphospholipid syndrome on warfarin therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (patient stopped consuming dill pickles, but no dosage details provided).
study_duration: Not specified (case report, no intervention duration mentioned).
interactions: Warfarin (abrupt dietary vitamin K change affected INR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of DIM supplementation on breast density in BRCA mutation carriers as a potential chemoprevention strategy.
results_summary: DIM supplementation (100 mg/day for 1 year) significantly reduced fibroglandular tissue (FGT) amount but did not affect background parenchymal enhancement (BPE). Hormonal levels (estradiol and testosterone) also decreased significantly. Side effects were mild (grade 1).
population_specificity: 23 healthy female BRCA carriers (median age 47 years; 78% postmenopausal).

study_goal: The researchers sought to validate a clinical prognostic score for predicting outcomes in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (aNSCLC) treated with second- or further-line immunotherapy.
results_summary: The prognostic score effectively categorized patients into three groups (best, intermediate, worst) with significantly different overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) outcomes. The worst prognosis group had a median OS of 2.6 months and likely would not benefit from active systemic therapy, suggesting best supportive care as the optimal choice.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (aNSCLC) from two Italian centers (median age 66 years, 70.7% male, 79.5% smokers, 74.6% adenocarcinoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining fixed sleep schedules with light regulation (morning light exposure via goggles and evening light reduction via amber-lens glasses) improves sleep consolidation in athletes.
results_summary: Light regulation improved self-reported sleep onset latency (8 minutes with lenient schedules, 17 minutes with strict schedules) and subjective sleep quality in athletes with strict sleep-wake schedules, but no significant differences were observed in actigraphy-based measures.
population_specificity: Twenty-six athletes (14 female, 12 male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (light exposure via goggles and amber-lens glasses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects and molecular mechanisms of DIM on carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver injury in mice.
results_summary: DIM significantly reduced serum transaminases, TNF-α, and ROS levels, inhibited apoptosis by lowering cleaved caspase-3 and Bax, and restored Cytochrome P450 2E1, Nrf2, and HO-1 expression while downregulating NF-κB.
population_specificity: Mice with CCl4-induced acute liver injury.
effective_dosage: 2.5, 5, and 10 mg/kg administered subcutaneously for three days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of ABCC3 expression and the SNP rs35467079 in CD56dim CD16+ NK cells in predicting patient outcomes following dendritic cell immunotherapy combined with temozolomide (TMZ) in glioblastoma.
results_summary: The study found that CD56dim CD16+ NK cells with high ABCC3 and IFN-γ expression were associated with better long-term survival and prognosis in glioblastoma patients. The SNP rs35467079 (-897DelC) in the ABCC3 promoter was linked to higher ABCC3 expression and improved patient outcomes, modulated by TMZ.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma patients treated with dendritic cell immunotherapy combined with TMZ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of pretreatment variables, including CD19 expression levels and prior CD19-targeted therapy, on the response to CAR T-cell therapy in relapsed/refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in CAR T-cell efficacy between CD19-dim, CD19-normal, or CD19-bright B-ALL, with CAR T-cells recognizing and lysing cells even at very low CD19 expression levels. However, prior therapy with blinatumomab was associated with higher rates of treatment failure or antigen escape.
population_specificity: 166 patients with relapsed/refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) treated with CAR T-cell therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the functional properties of NK cell subsets (CD56dim and CD56bright) in patients with HBV-related decompensated liver cirrhosis (HBV-DLC) and their relationship with liver function decompensation.
results_summary: The study found that HBV-DLC patients had increased circulating CD56bright NK cells with higher immune activation and decreased CD56dim NK cells with impaired cytolytic capacity, which correlated with liver function decompensation.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with HBV-related decompensated liver cirrhosis (HBV-DLC), 25 patients with HBV-related compensated liver cirrhosis (HBV-CLC), and 25 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of VS38 as an alternative to bright CD38 for identifying plasma cells, particularly in myeloma cases with dim CD38 or after daratumumab treatment.
results_summary: The study found that VS38 was a viable alternative for identifying plasma cells, with no significant difference in clonal plasma cell percentages between VS38 and standard panels. Daratumumab interference with CD38 identification persisted for 4 to 6 months after the last exposure.
population_specificity: 38 patients (63 specimens), including 26 who had received daratumumab therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DIM could inhibit proliferation, migration, and invasion of RA-FLSs and reduce proinflammatory factors in rheumatoid arthritis, both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: DIM inhibited RA-FLS proliferation, migration, and invasion in vitro, suppressed TNF-α-induced increases in MMPs and proinflammatory cytokines, and alleviated arthritis severity in AIA mice by blocking MAPK and AKT/mTOR pathways.
population_specificity: RA fibroblast-like synoviocytes (RA-FLSs) from RA patients and adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dim artificial light at night (DLAN) on wound healing in mice.
results_summary: DLAN prior to wounding impaired healing, with mice in DLAN/DLAN and DLAN/LD conditions showing significantly larger wounds and increased time to closure compared to controls.
population_specificity: Female C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the predictive value of CD45dimCD117+ phenotype-abnormal cells for relapse and prognosis in adult AML patients within 2 weeks after first complete remission (CR1).
results_summary: The study found that a CD45dimCD117+ abnormal cell ratio >2.055% within 2 weeks after CR1 was an independent risk factor for relapse and adversely affected recurrence-free survival (RFS) and overall survival (OS). Patients with higher abnormal cell ratios had significantly lower 2-year RFS and OS rates compared to those with lower ratios.
population_specificity: Adult patients with newly diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (non-acute promyelocytic leukemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the challenges in diagnosing and assessing minimal residual disease (MRD) in CD19 negative or dim B-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) and discuss alternative gating strategies.
results_summary: The study presented a cohort of 14 de novo CD19 negative and dim B-ALL cases, emphasizing diagnostic and MRD assessment difficulties, particularly in the context of CD19-targeted immunotherapy. It underscored the need for alternative B-lineage markers and strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with CD19 negative or dim B-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ability of dill seed extract to improve skin elasticity in vitro and in vivo using different models.
results_summary: The study found that dill extract significantly increased skin elasticity in vitro (+29%) and improved skin firmness, elastic recovery, and appearance in vivo, with reductions in wrinkle area and length. Clinical evaluations and subject reports confirmed these improvements.
population_specificity: Volunteers (specific demographics not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photodynamic larvicidal activity of novel phthalocyanines (PC) and other photosensitizers (PS) against Aedes mosquito larvae and their cell lines.
results_summary: Three novel phthalocyanines (amino-Si-PC1, -PC2, anilinium Zn-PC3.4, pyridyloxy Si-PC14) and two porphyrin derivatives (TPPS2, TMAP) demonstrated effective photodynamic inactivation of mosquito larvae, with EC50 values in the nanomolar range, outperforming classic PS like rose bengal and cyanosine. These PS also dose-dependently inactivated mosquito cells in vitro, supporting their larvicidal mechanism.
population_specificity: Laboratory-reared Aedes mosquito larvae and their cell lines.
effective_dosage: Graded concentrations (specific amounts not provided) followed by light exposure.
study_duration: Overnight PS exposure in the dark, followed by up to 7 hours of dim light exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) and perovskite solar cells (PSCs) under dim-light conditions (200 lux irradiation).
results_summary: Cobalt-based DSCs achieved a power conversion efficiency of 16.0% under 200 lux, outperforming iodine-based DSCs, while PSCs showed even higher efficiency (23.4%) with superior open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current density.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on solar cell technology, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of IL-35 in regulating the balance between viral-specific Tregs and Th17 cells in chronic HBV infection.
results_summary: IL-35 stimulation increased viral-specific Tregs and elevated the Tregs/Th17 ratio in chronic HBV patients, accompanied by increased FoxP3 mRNA expression and IL-10 production, while reducing IL-17 secretion and STAT3 phosphorylation. Anti-HBV therapy did not affect Tregs/Th17 frequency but reduced responsiveness to IL-35 stimulation.
population_specificity: 44 HLA-A2 restricted chronic HBV-infected patients (21 with chronic hepatitis B and 23 asymptomatic carriers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of Notch signaling in modulating Tregs and Th17 cell function in gastric cancer patients, using the Notch signaling inhibitor DAPT.
results_summary: DAPT treatment reduced FoxP3/RORγt mRNA expression and IL-35/IL-17 production in purified CD4+ T cells from GC patients, and inhibited the suppressive function of Tregs, leading to increased cellular proliferation and IL-35 secretion.
population_specificity: 51 gastric cancer patients and 18 normal controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DIM could protect against ionizing radiation-induced intestinal injury in mice and human intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: DIM administration protected mice from whole abdominal irradiation-induced lethality, weight loss, and intestinal damage, while also enhancing intestinal stem cell recovery and reducing oxidative stress and DNA damage in human intestinal epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to whole abdominal irradiation and human intestinal epithelial cells (HIEC-6) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the mechanisms by which IVIG suppresses effector cell activities, particularly CD56dim NK cells, in antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).
results_summary: IVIG exposure induced caspase-3-dependent apoptosis in CD56dim NK cells, suppressing ADCC effector activities, an effect linked to the monomer fraction of IVIG and independent of IgG sialyation or FcγRIII engagement.
population_specificity: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC), specifically CD56dim NK cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the regulatory activity of DAAs (daclatasvir plus asunaprevir) on TLR2 stimulation in Tregs and Th17 cells in chronic hepatitis C patients.
results_summary: The study found that daclatasvir and asunaprevir therapy did not affect Tregs/Th17 cell percentages or TLR2 expression but reduced their responsiveness to TLR2 stimulation, enhancing Treg suppressive function and IL-35 production only at baseline.
population_specificity: 23 patients with chronic HCV genotype 1b infection.
study_duration: Treatment duration until end of therapy (EOT) and follow-up until 12 weeks after EOT (SVR12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether immune system reconstruction was possible in chronic hepatitis B (CHB) patients after treatment with nucleoside (acid) analogs (NAs) and viral replication inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that circulating CD56dim NK cells and the Th17/Treg balance could be recovered after NA treatment, potentially aiding in reducing HBsAg levels. Additionally, certain immune cell frequencies (e.g., CD40L+CXCR5+CD4+T cells, CD40+CD19+CD27+CD38+B cells) were altered compared to healthy controls.
population_specificity: Chronic hepatitis B (CHB) patients with HBV-DNA levels <1000 IU/mL, HBeAg disappearance, and decreased HBsAg levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-intensity artificial light at night (ALAN) on bank vole behavior and physiology over winter and early breeding season.
results_summary: Bank voles exposed to ALAN showed altered daily activity patterns and space use behavior, with increased nighttime activity during half moon and larger day ranges during new moon, but no differences in survival, body mass, or fecal glucocorticoid metabolites.
population_specificity: Bank voles (Myodes glareolus) in large grassland enclosures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new MATLAB-based tracking program combining manual and automatic tracking methods to study the dynamics of biological molecules like β-actin mRNA in neurons.
results_summary: The study demonstrated the utility of the tracking program by showing that the diffusion coefficient of β-actin mRNA decreases upon neuronal stimulation by bicuculline treatment in cultured hippocampal neurons. The method efficiently dissected dynamic regulation in complex intracellular environments.
population_specificity: Cultured hippocampal neurons

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Natural Killer (NK) cells in the clearance of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) during acute infection and identify distinct NK-cell profiles associated with early and late HBV surface antigen (HBsAg) clearance.
results_summary: The study found that the CD56dim NK-cell subset was selectively activated during acute HBV infection, with distinct phenotypic and functional profiles linked to efficient and early control of HBV. These profiles predicted time to HBsAg clearance, with early clearance associated with elevated degranulation and late clearance linked to IFNγ production.
population_specificity: Adults with acute HBV infection (excluding immunocompromised individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective role of DIM against doxorubicin (DOX)-induced toxicity in mice, focusing on oxidative stress, DNA damage, and apoptosis.
results_summary: DIM significantly reduced DOX-induced oxidative stress, DNA damage, and apoptosis while enhancing antioxidant activity and cytoprotective protein expression. It also mitigated DOX-induced clastogenicity and myeloid hyperplasia in bone marrow.
population_specificity: Mice treated with doxorubicin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-utility of collaborative care (CC) for treating comorbid major depressive disorder (MDD) in chronically ill patients in an outpatient general hospital setting.
results_summary: The study found that CC was more costly but also more effective than care as usual (CAU), with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of €24,690 per quality-adjusted life year (QALY). However, the low utility scores suggest the need for further research to improve CC's cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Chronically ill patients with moderate-to-severe MDD in an outpatient general hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the phenotypic and functional features of a newly identified CD56dimCD16dim NK cell subpopulation in various immune conditions.
results_summary: The study identified a distinct CD56dimCD16dim NK cell subset with unique phenotypic and functional properties, showing differential responses in HIV-1-infected individuals and other immunodeficient conditions. This subset exhibited higher degranulation than CD56dimCD16bright cells but less than CD56dimCD16- NK cells.
population_specificity: Healthy donors, HIV-1-infected individuals, transporter associated with antigen processing-deficient patients, familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis type II patients, and common variable immunodeficiency patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether red fluorescence in the triplefin Tripterygion delaisi improves foraging success under blue-green, heavily shaded light conditions.
results_summary: Fish were 7% more successful at catching copepods under a narrow, fluorescence-friendly spectrum compared to a broad spectrum, but this effect was only significant under heavily shaded light conditions. The findings suggest fluorescence may be an adaptation to blue-green, heavily shaded environments.
population_specificity: Triplefin fish (Tripterygion delaisi)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dim light at night (dLAN) on depressive-like phenotypes in mice, particularly focusing on the role of the Period3 gene and the potential alleviation of these effects by imipramine.
results_summary: Both wild-type and Per3-/- mice showed elevated corticosterone and hippocampal Bdnf expression after 3 weeks of dLAN exposure, but only Per3-/- mice exhibited transient anhedonia-like behavior (reduced sucrose preference). Imipramine treatment prevented these phenotypes in both genotypes.
population_specificity: Mice (wild-type and Per3-/-)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize NK cell subsets, phenotype, and function in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) patients to understand their role in disease activity and remission.
results_summary: The study found that NK cell counts inversely correlate with GPA activity, with reduced CD56(dim) NK cells in active GPA showing an activated phenotype but deficient cytotoxicity, which was restored in remission.
population_specificity: Patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) (cohort II, n=22; combined cohorts I and II, n=34/57).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a reduced sampling protocol (60-min intervals) could accurately measure dim light melatonin onset (DLMO) compared to a standard 30-min protocol in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that 60-min sampling provided DLMO estimates within ±1 hour of the 30-min sampling, but only when using absolute thresholds (3 or 4 pg/mL). The agreement was not consistent when using a relative threshold (mean + 2 SDs).
population_specificity: 66 healthy adolescents (26 males) aged 14.8-17.8 years.
study_duration: Two partial 6-hour salivary melatonin profiles per participant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Infemin (a DIM-based drug with improved bioavailability) in treating high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).
results_summary: Infemin significantly reduced the morphological index (MI) and achieved complete PIN regression in 45.5% of patients, unlike placebo. However, improvements in urodynamic parameters and other secondary outcomes were not statistically significant, likely due to the small sample size.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy and feasibility of a home saliva collection kit for measuring dim light melatonin onset (DLMO) in individuals with delayed sleep phase disorder (DSPD).
results_summary: The home DLMOs were highly correlated with laboratory DLMOs (r = 0.93, P < 0.001), with 83% unaffected by light or sampling errors. Home DLMOs occurred, on average, 10.2 minutes earlier than laboratory DLMOs.
population_specificity: 32 participants with delayed sleep phase disorder (17 women, aged 18-52 years).
study_duration: Two back-to-back home and laboratory phase assessments (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cancer-specific toxicity and efficacy of the peptide R-DIM-P-LF11-334, a derivative of lactoferricin, in targeting melanoma cells while sparing non-neoplastic cells.
results_summary: R-DIM-P-LF11-334 showed high cytotoxicity against melanoma cells (A375 and MUG Mel1) with an LC50 of ~10 μM, while minimally affecting non-neoplastic fibroblasts, demonstrating a 20-fold killing specificity. In vivo, the peptide induced strong tumor regression, reducing tumor area by 85% in mouse xenografts.
population_specificity: Human malignant melanoma cell lines (A375, MUG Mel1) and non-neoplastic human dermal fibroblasts (NHDF); mouse xenografts of human melanoma.
effective_dosage: LC50 ~10 μM (in vitro); dosage in vivo not specified.
study_duration: Duration of in vivo intervention not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if stem/progenitor cell (SPC) assays during early wound care could predict healing outcomes in diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: Higher SPC numbers and HIF levels in the first weeks of care predicted successful healing within 16 weeks. Logistic regression showed these factors were significant predictors of healing.
population_specificity: 100 patients with diabetic neuropathic foot ulcers undergoing standard wound management.
study_duration: 8 weeks of sample collection and monitoring

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the percentage of peripheral blood CD56(+) NK cells (CD56(dim) and CD56(bright)) between women with IVF failure and successful IVF controls.
results_summary: The study found that women with IVF failure had significantly higher levels of CD56(dim) CD16(+) NK cells compared to successful IVF controls, while CD56(bright) CD16(-) NK cell levels showed no significant difference. The results suggest that elevated CD56(dim) NK cells may be associated with IVF failure.
population_specificity: 50 women undergoing IVF treatment (32% successful IVF, 68% IVF failure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of antiretroviral treatment (ART) on the immune restoration of natural killer (NK) cells, including terminal differentiation, activation, and distribution in HIV-1 patients.
results_summary: ART restored the disturbed distribution of NK cell subsets, partially reduced immune activation, and enhanced terminal differentiation of CD56(dim)CD16(+) NK cells, correlating with increased total NK cell frequencies.
population_specificity: Treatment-naive HIV-1 patients and healthy controls.

study_goal: To evaluate the role of uterine natural killer (uNK) CD56dim and CD16+ cells in patients with refractory antiphospholipid antibody-mediated recurrent pregnancy loss.
results_summary: The study found that aberrant CD56dim and CD16+ uNK cells were present in 81.4% of cases with refractory antiphospholipid antibody-mediated recurrent pregnancy loss, suggesting a potential correlation. Abnormal fetal karyotype accounted for only 9.3% of treatment failures.
population_specificity: 118 women with a history of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome experiencing fetal loss despite treatment with low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the role of microRNAs in hepatitis B virus-related liver diseases, including their potential as diagnostic markers and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that microRNAs are involved in hepatitis B virus replication, extracellular matrix formation, and tumor suppressor gene silencing, contributing to chronic hepatitis, liver fibrosis/cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. They also suggested microRNAs could serve as diagnostic markers and therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatitis B virus-related liver diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of MEQ and MSFsc questionnaires in predicting DLMO (dim light melatonin onset) as a measure of circadian timing.
results_summary: Both MEQ and MSFsc significantly correlated with DLMO (r = -0.70 and r = 0.68, respectively), with MSFsc being the strongest predictor. However, neither questionnaire alone should be used exclusively for timing treatments due to a 4-hour DLMO variability at given scores.
population_specificity: 36 healthy controls and 24 patients with delayed sleep phase disorder, aged 18-62.
study_duration: Participants slept at their own chosen times for a week before DLMO assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether blue light pulses delivered through closed eyelids via a sleep mask could effectively suppress melatonin and delay circadian phase in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that blue light pulses significantly suppressed melatonin and delayed circadian phase in older adults, demonstrating efficacy and practicality for home-based light therapy.
population_specificity: Older adults with potential circadian rhythm disturbances.
effective_dosage: 480 nm (blue) light pulses of 2-second duration every 30 seconds for 1 hour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of Infemin (a high-bioavailability DIM formulation) in men with prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and discuss interim results.
results_summary: The study found that Infemin had minimal toxicity and no serious adverse events, with only three mild adverse events (nausea and diarrhea) reported in two patients. The formulation was well-tolerated, supporting further clinical trials for efficacy and long-term safety.
population_specificity: 14 men diagnosed with prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the presence and role of CD14dimCD16+ and CD14brightCD16+ monocyte subsets in lung infiltrative alveolar macrophages in chronic beryllium disease (CBD) and beryllium-sensitized individuals.
results_summary: The study found that CD14dimCD16+ cells were decreased in PBMCs of CBD and beryllium-sensitized non-smokers but were present in alveolar macrophages, with altered expression of markers like CD16, CD40, CD86, and HLA-DR. Beryllium exposure downregulated CD16 expression and reduced phagocytic activity in these macrophages.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic beryllium disease (CBD), beryllium-sensitized non-smokers (BeS-NS), beryllium-sensitized smokers (BeS-S), and healthy subjects (HS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the Multidisciplinary Multistep Medication Review (3MR) in discontinuing inappropriate medication among nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study found that the 3MR intervention was designed to optimize prescribing and discontinue inappropriate medication, with primary outcomes focusing on the proportion of residents who successfully discontinued such medications. Secondary outcomes included undertreatment, exposure to anticholinergic and sedative medicines, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cognitive function, falls, hospital admission, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents, with more than half expected to suffer from dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Neurospora crassa exhibits molecular circadian rhythms in dim light after prior exposure to bright light, termed the "bright to dim oscillatory response" (BDOR).
results_summary: The study found that Neurospora can display circadian rhythms in dim light if previously exposed to bright light, with the effect lasting up to 76 hours and requiring as little as 15 minutes of bright light. The response was characterized based on light pulse duration, timing, dim light intensity, and oscillation dynamics.
population_specificity: Neurospora crassa (fungus)
study_duration: Bright light exposure as short as 15 minutes, with effects observed up to 76 hours later

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if different oxygen partial pressures (2.0 vs. 2.5 ATA) during hyperbaric oxygen treatment affected the mobilization efficiency of bone marrow-derived stem/progenitor cells.
results_summary: Post-treatment CD34+ and CD45-dim leukocyte levels were consistently 2-fold higher than pre-treatment levels for both protocols, with significantly greater mobilization (1.9 to 3-fold) at 2.5 ATA compared to 2.0 ATA. Newly mobilized cells showed elevated concentrations of regulatory proteins, but no significant differences between the two oxygen protocols.
population_specificity: Twenty consecutive patients at two clinical centers.
effective_dosage: Oxygen exposure at 2.0 or 2.5 atmospheres absolute (ATA).
study_duration: Up to 20 treatments (duration per treatment not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the importance of timing melatonin administration based on individual circadian timing (DLMO) for optimal treatment of circadian rhythm sleep disorders (CRSD).
results_summary: The study found that melatonin and other treatments for CRSD are most effective when administered according to individual circadian timing (DLMO), rather than a fixed pre-bedtime schedule. Incorrect timing may render treatments ineffective or produce contrary effects. Measuring DLMO via saliva can improve diagnosis and treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with circadian rhythm sleep disorders (CRSD) or insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on timing rather than dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize CD14(+) mononuclear cell populations in intestinal mucosa and blood in patients with Crohn's disease (CD) and identify their role in intestinal inflammation.
results_summary: The study identified three distinct HLA-DR(+)-expressing subsets among LP CD14(+) M, with inflamed mucosa showing a marked increase in CD14(hi)HLA-DR(dim) cells. These cells resembled classical blood monocytes, migrated efficiently toward CCL2, and released high levels of MMP-1 and proinflammatory cytokines when stimulated.
population_specificity: Patients with Crohn's disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BR-DIM (a form of DIM) could reexpress miR-34a and subsequently inactivate AR signaling in prostate cancer (PCa) to prevent castrate-resistant progression.
results_summary: BR-DIM intervention in PCa patients led to reexpression of miR-34a, reduced AR, PSA, and Notch-1 expression, and promoted nuclear exclusion of AR. In vitro, BR-DIM combined with 5-aza-dC demethylated the miR-34a promoter, inhibiting AR and PSA expression.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients (pre-radical prostatectomy) and PCa cell lines (LNCaP and C4-2B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether AMPK is a molecular target of B-DIM in human prostate cancer cells and to elucidate its anti-cancer mechanisms.
results_summary: B-DIM activated the AMPK signaling pathway, suppressed mTOR, down-regulated AR expression, and induced apoptosis in both androgen-sensitive and androgen-insensitive prostate cancer cells. It also showed similar effects in androgen-independent prostate tumor xenografts in mice.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer cells (LNCaP and C4-2B) and SCID mice with C4-2B xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a practical, non-invasive method to estimate circadian phase using ambulatory monitoring devices, focusing on skin temperature, motor activity, and body position, and compare it to dim light melatonin onset (DLMO).
results_summary: The study found that evening increases in wrist skin temperature (WTiO) accurately predicted DLMO, with high correlation (R=0.756). Subjective sleep and composite variables (TAP) also showed significant correlations with DLMO, supporting a new method for circadian phase estimation.
population_specificity: 13 subjects wearing ambulatory monitoring devices and maintaining daily routines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dim nocturnal illumination (0.03 lx) could accelerate reentrainment of circadian rhythms in Drosophila biarmipes following simulated jetlag.
results_summary: The study found that dimly lit nights (0.03 lx) significantly accelerated reentrainment compared to complete darkness (0 lx) in both phase advance and delay scenarios, suggesting potential as a non-drug jetlag treatment. The effect was consistent and faster than melatonin in the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Drosophila biarmipes (fruit flies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DIM selectively inhibits cancer stem cells (CSCs) and overcomes chemoresistance in various cancer cell lines.
results_summary: DIM inhibited tumor sphere formation at concentrations 30-300 times lower than those needed for parental cell growth inhibition and enhanced sensitivity to chemotherapeutics like paclitaxel, doxorubicin, and SN-38. Pre-treatment with DIM before implantation in mice significantly slowed primary tumor growth.
population_specificity: Cancer cell lines and mouse models.
effective_dosage: Concentrations achievable in human plasma after oral dosing (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the percentage of peripheral blood CD56(+) NK cells (CD56(dim) and CD56(bright)) and NK cell cytotoxicity levels in patients with recurrent spontaneous abortion (RSA) and IVF failure versus healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that RSA patients and women with IVF failure had significantly higher percentages of CD56(dim) cells and higher NK cytotoxicity levels compared to healthy multiparous and successful IVF control groups. These findings suggest that elevated CD56(dim) cells and NK cytotoxicity may contribute to RSA and IVF failure.
population_specificity: 43 patients (23 with RSA, 20 with IVF failure) and 43 healthy controls (36 multiparous women, 7 with successful IVF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BR-DIM (formulated DIM) could attenuate prostate cancer aggressiveness by modulating let-7 and EZH2 expression.
results_summary: BR-DIM treatment upregulated let-7 and downregulated EZH2, inhibiting self-renewal and clonogenic capacity in prostate cancer cells. Clinical trial data showed similar effects in prostate tissue specimens after BR-DIM intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with prostate cancer, particularly those in an ongoing phase II clinical trial prior to radical prostatectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of DIM mutations (hGR(dim) and hGR(dim4)) in glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis and gene expression regulation in human osteosarcoma cells.
results_summary: The study found that hGR(dim) cells were partially resistant to glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis, while hGR(dim4) cells were completely resistant. Both mutations retained dimerization ability but showed differential gene regulation compared to wild-type hGRα.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma (U-2 OS) cells devoid of hGR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BR-DIM (a form of DIM) could re-express miR-34a and subsequently inactivate AR signaling in prostate cancer, potentially preventing castrate-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).
results_summary: BR-DIM intervention in prostate cancer patients led to re-expression of miR-34a, reduced AR and PSA expression, and nuclear exclusion of AR in tumor tissues. In vitro, BR-DIM combined with 5-aza-dC demethylated the miR-34a promoter, further suppressing AR and PSA in prostate cancer cells.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients (pre-radical prostatectomy) and prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP and C4-2B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether B-DIM enhances the effects of radiotherapy in hormone-refractory prostate cancer cells, regardless of androgen receptor (AR) expression.
results_summary: B-DIM inhibited cell growth and increased radiation-induced cell killing in both AR-positive and AR-negative prostate cancer cell lines. It also blocked radiation-induced activation of NF-κB and HIF-1α, reduced AR nuclear localization, and inhibited tumor growth and metastasis in mice.
population_specificity: Hormone-refractory prostate cancer cells (PC-3 and C4-2B cell lines) and nude mice with PC-3 prostate tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the anti-tumor and biological effects of DIM, focusing on its potential as a chemopreventive agent and its ability to modulate key cellular pathways in cancer cells.
results_summary: DIM demonstrated pleiotropic anti-tumor effects, including inducing apoptosis, suppressing cell proliferation, and modulating signaling pathways like Ah receptor, NF-κB/Wnt/Akt/mTOR. Preclinical models showed selective apoptosis in tumor cells, and DIM has progressed to Phase I clinical trials.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and Phase I clinical trials (human malignancies).

study_goal: The abstract does not mention DIM or its study goals.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss DIM or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on NK cells, not DIM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of discontinuing short-term melatonin treatment on sleep, health, behavior, and parenting stress in children with delayed Dim Light Melatonin Onset.
results_summary: Melatonin treatment improved sleep latency, sleep start time, actual sleep time, health, behavior problems, and parenting stress, but these benefits diminished or disappeared after discontinuation. Sleep efficiency deteriorated after stopping treatment, and the positive effects on Dim Light Melatonin Onset were not sustained post-treatment.
population_specificity: 41 children (24 boys, 17 girls; mean age 9.43 years) with delayed Dim Light Melatonin Onset.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment involved full dose for 3 weeks, half dose for 1 week, then discontinuation).
study_duration: 4 weeks (3 weeks full dose, 1 week half dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of primary gastric T-cell lymphoma (PGTL) and review its clinical, pathologic, and molecular features for diagnosis and classification.
results_summary: The study described a 68-year-old male with PGTL presenting as gastric perforation, detailing histologic, immunohistochemical, and molecular findings. It also reviewed literature to highlight diagnostic and prognostic features of this rare lymphoma.
population_specificity: Elderly male (68 years old) with primary gastric T-cell lymphoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the regulatory roles of I3C and DIM in liver diseases, including their potential benefits in treating hepatocellular carcinoma and nonmalignant liver conditions.
results_summary: The study found that I3C and DIM exhibit dual roles in liver disorders, inhibiting and promoting hepatocellular carcinoma while providing relief for nonmalignant liver diseases. They modulate processes like cell proliferation, apoptosis, oxidative stress, and lipogenesis.
population_specificity: Liver disease models (HCC, ALI, hepatic fibrosis, NAFLD, ALD)

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing current treatment approaches to abort acute CVS and CHS episodes, not specifically studying DIM.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention DIM or its effects, focusing instead on pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic interventions for CVS and CHS.
population_specificity: Patients with cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) and cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify NK cell phenotypes associated with viral infection versus alloreactive events in pediatric kidney transplant recipients and examine their relationship with long-term patient and allograft survival.
results_summary: The study found that specific baseline NK cell phenotypes prior to transplantation may predict viral infection or alloimmunity risk, with elevated CD56 levels linked to viral infection and lower levels associated with alloimmunity. NK cell phenotyping could help differentiate infectious from alloimmune risk.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-20 years old who received kidney transplants.
study_duration: First year post-transplantation (with 7-year survival follow-up via SRTR database).

study_goal: The study aimed to identify host and bacterial factors associated with vaginal microbiome stability to better inform therapeutic interventions for bacterial vaginosis (BV).
results_summary: The study found increased microbial diversity in non-Lactobacillus-dominant microbiomes (P = 3.1E-05) and identified 73 bacterial species, 1773 mucosal proteins, and 117 metabolites through multi-omics profiling. Initial flow cytometry analysis showed increased CD4+ T cells and neutrophil activation in BV+ participants.
population_specificity: Women treated for BV and controls in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover GZMK expression profiles across various immune cell types using single-cell RNA sequencing meta-analysis.
results_summary: GZMK was most lowly expressed in NK cells and mature NKT cells in most tissues except colon and lymph nodes, with higher expression in effector memory CD8-positive T cells. Unique transcription factor binding sites for GZMK were identified, suggesting distinct regulatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: Immune cell types (mature T cells, NK cells, B cells, NKT cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of physical activity timing on insomnia severity and circadian clock function in older adults.
